commit_message:
Fix options for nova flavor-access-list

The text misses the --flavor option which is required:

$ nova help flavor-access-list
usage: nova flavor-access-list [--flavor <flavor>] [--tenant
<tenant_id>]

Add --flavor to nova flavor-access-list.

Change-Id: I374b2107b499be12f9e08e8d7deb0a07b4cacee1
Closes-Bug: #1315476
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/operations-guide refs/changes/41/91941/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-25 05:09:08.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/stress/actions/ssh_floating.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/d789b546fc43b44d565ca23ca30aa3c9cb0742b3', 'message': 'ssh_floating verify reboot

The reboot true option is usually useful for generate more ovs
events, but actually it can fail on the machine remains in SHUTOFF
state. A status check added, in order to help identify this situation.

The icmp echo test generated more logs than it required.
The intermediate pings will not be logged.

Change-Id: I524da1f2324227ef77755c070430221918e1694e
'}]
commit_message:
ssh_floating verify reboot

The reboot true option is usually useful for generate more ovs
events, but actually it can fail on the machine remains in SHUTOFF
state. A status check added, in order to help identify this situation.

The icmp echo test generated more logs than it required.
The intermediate pings will not be logged.

Change-Id: I524da1f2324227ef77755c070430221918e1694e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/83/90283/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.logger.info("%s(%s): Pinging..", self.server_id, self.floating['ip']) raise RuntimeError("%s(%s): Cannot ping the machine.", self.server_id, self.floating['ip']) self.logger.info("%s(%s): pong :)", self.server_id, self.floating['ip']) self.manager.servers_client.wait_for_server_status(self.server_id, 'ACTIVE')
deleted_lines: self.logger.info("%s(%s): %s", self.server_id, self.floating['ip'], "pong!" if success else "no pong :(") raise RuntimeError("Cannot ping the machine.")

commit_message:
Add Neutron benchmarks scenarios

This patch contains:
- Changes for supporting neutron scenario tests
- Add scenario "create_and_list_networks"

blueprint benchmark-scenarios-for-neutron

Change-Id: Ic6ba1b1b832529ef48c08f106473c5914a2d1564

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from rally.benchmark.scenarios.neutron import network from tests import test NEUTRON_NETWORKS = "rally.benchmark.scenarios.neutron.network.NeutronNetworks" class NeutronNetworksTestCase(test.TestCase): @mock.patch(NEUTRON_NETWORKS + "._generate_neutron_name") @mock.patch(NEUTRON_NETWORKS + "._list_networks") @mock.patch(NEUTRON_NETWORKS + "._create_network") def test_create_and_list_image(self, mock_create, mock_list, mock_random_name): neutron_scenario = network.NeutronNetworks() mock_random_name.return_value = "test-rally-network" neutron_scenario.create_and_list_networks() mock_create.assert_called_once_with("test-rally-network") mock_list.assert_called_once_with()

commit_message:
Synced jsonutils from oslo-incubator

The sync includes change that drastically enhances performance on Python
2.6 with fresh simplejson library installed.

The latest commit in oslo-incubator:
- 732bdb6297eb9de81667f7713ebcb1ccc2ee45a7

Change-Id: Ib3dc0b713ed90396919feba018772243b3b9c90f

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-network refs/changes/57/90357/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: default['openstack']['network']['service_plugins'] = []# Maps the above core plugin driver to a simple name # This is used in the neutron_plugin_package package name and common recipe case statements default['openstack']['network']['core_plugin_map'] = { 'ovsneutronpluginv2' => 'openvswitch', 'linuxbridgepluginv2' => 'linuxbridge', 'ml2plugin' => 'ml2' } # This is used by SUSE to setup the sysconfig neutron initfile default['openstack']['network']['plugin_conf_map'] = { 'ovsneutronpluginv2' => 'openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini', 'linuxbridgepluginv2' => 'linuxbridge/linuxbridge_conf.ini', 'ml2plugin' => 'ml2/ml2_conf.ini' }
deleted_lines: default['openstack']['network']['service_plugins'] = 'neutron.services.l3_router.l3_router_plugin.L3RouterPlugin'## maps the above driver to a plugin name default['openstack']['network']['interface_driver_map'] = { 'ovsinterfacedriver' => 'openvswitch', 'bridgeinterfacedriver' => 'linuxbridge', 'ml2interfacedriver' => 'ml2' } default['openstack']['network']['plugin_conf_map'] = { 'ovsinterfacedriver' => 'openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini', 'bridgeinterfacedriver' => 'linuxbridge/linuxbridge_conf.ini', 'ml2interfacedriver' => 'ml2/ml2_conf.ini' }

commit_message:
"Some changes of common"

Change-Id: I3ab1b0210b673ff967cf93dac5927af8b9360f59
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-network refs/changes/58/90358/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: driver_name = node['openstack']['network']['interface_driver'].split('.').last.downcase main_plugin = node['openstack']['network']['interface_driver_map'][driver_name]template '/etc/neutron/policy.json' do source 'policy.json.erb' owner node['openstack']['network']['platform']['user'] group node['openstack']['network']['platform']['group'] mode 00644 notifies :restart, 'service[neutron-server]', :delayed end if node['openstack']['network']['api']['bind_interface'].nil? bind_address = api_endpoint.host bind_port = api_endpoint.port else bind_address = address_for node['openstack']['network']['api']['bind_interface'] bind_port = node['openstack']['network']['api']['bind_port'] end # retrieve the local interface for tunnels if node['openstack']['network']['linuxbridge']['local_ip_interface'].nil? local_ip = node['openstack']['network']['linuxbridge']['local_ip'] else local_ip = address_for node['openstack']['network']['linuxbridge']['local_ip_interface'] end # retrieve the local interface for tunnels if node['openstack']['network']['linuxbridge']['local_ip_interface'].nil? local_ip = node['openstack']['network']['linuxbridge']['local_ip'] else local_ip = address_for node['openstack']['network']['linuxbridge']['local_ip_interface'] end # retrieve the local interface for tunnels if node['openstack']['network']['openvswitch']['local_ip_interface'].nil? local_ip = node['openstack']['network']['openvswitch']['local_ip'] else local_ip = address_for node['openstack']['network']['openvswitch']['local_ip_interface'] endif core_plugin.split('.').last == "Ml2Plugin" template "/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini" do source 'plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini.erb' owner node['openstack']['network']['platform']['user'] group node['openstack']['network']['platform']['group'] mode 00644 notifies :create, "link[#{plugin_file}]", :immediately notifies :restart, 'service[neutron-server]', :delayed end end

commit_message:
Allow policy.json file to be specified

The policy.json file was removed in 853fa9fcc6d7e9e6607be188299bf6c9208f24f7
this will allow you to specify an attribute to point to a location of a
policy.json file to be used.

By default this is nil and the packaged policy.json file will be used,
but if required this can be overridden.

Change-Id: I2d21211e24e64d7046cf3782400310eb1bff4500
Implements: blueprint remote-policy

commit_message:
Add management interface,data interface,external interface

Change-Id: I473bf3d7fc4b45581eb6e4d522925b29359a11a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-network refs/changes/68/92068/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: management_interface = node['openstack']['network']['linuxbridge']['management_interface'] data_interface = node['openstack']['network']['linuxbridge']['data_interface'] external_interface = node['openstack']['network']['linuxbridge']['external_interface'] local_ip = address_for data_interface interfaces = [management_interface, data_interface, external_interface].uniq i = 0 while i < interfaces.size interfaces[i] = 'physnet'.concat((i + 1).to_s).concat(':').concat(interfaces[i]) i += 1 end physical_interface_mappings = interfaces.join(',') template_file = '/etc/neutron/plugins/linuxbridge/linuxbridge_conf.ini' template template_file do source 'plugins/linuxbridge/linuxbridge_conf.ini.erb' owner node['openstack']['network']['platform']['user'] group node['openstack']['network']['platform']['group'] mode 00644 variables( local_ip: local_ip, physical_interface_mappings: physical_interface_mappings ) notifies :restart, 'service[neutron-plugin-linuxbridge-agent]', :immediately end

and defaults to null.

added_lines: def get_next_dev_path_suffix(suffix): """Return next device name suffix. :param suffix: is changable part of device name, in /dev/vdb it is 'b' and in /dev/vdab it is 'ab'. Allowed only lower case. :returns: str -- next suffix after provided :raises: exception.InvalidInput Examples: >>> get_next_dev_path("y") z >>> get_next_dev_path("z") aa """ begin = "a" end = "z" min_number = ord(begin) max_number = ord(end) letters = list(suffix) error_msg = _("Invalid dev path suffix supplied '%s'.") % suffix for s in letters: if ord(s) not in range(min_number, max_number + 1): raise exception.InvalidInput(error_msg) if len(letters) == 0: raise exception.InvalidInput(error_msg) else: current_number = ord(letters[-1]) if current_number in range(min_number, max_number): letters[-1] = chr(current_number + 1) elif current_number == max_number: letters[-1] = begin if len(letters) == 1: letters.insert(0, begin) else: prefix = get_next_dev_path_suffix(''.join(letters[:-1])) return prefix + letters[-1] else: raise exception.InvalidInput(error_msg) return ''.join(letters)

subject: Enable unpickling base.Resource objects
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-29 12:33:52.000000000', 'files': ['muranoclient/common/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-muranoclient/commit/4544ddfb7c37618127e3b540c59dee5bdda004ab', 'message': 'Enable unpickling base.Resource objects

If no __setstate__ method provided, an infinite recursion occurs during unpickling.

Change-Id: I2c9026e8af20b6e54133b8a2c44b82cfd599e9af
'}]
commit_message:
Enable unpickling base.Resource objects

If no __setstate__ method provided, an infinite recursion occurs during unpickling.

Change-Id: I2c9026e8af20b6e54133b8a2c44b82cfd599e9af
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-muranoclient refs/changes/98/90998/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __setstate__(self, d): for k, v in d.iteritems(): setattr(self, k, v)

commit_message:
Fix H302 violations in plugins package

H302 violation is reported by flake8 when importing separated objects from
modules instead of importing the whole module.
e.g.   from package.module import function
       function()
is changed to
       from package import module
       module.function()

Change-Id: I83372124f4fba7b94bbfb4a56a0c0ef779ee237f
Partial-Bug: #1291032

subject: Port initialize() and friends to Keystone v2
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-01 06:09:38.000000000', 'files': ['os_cloud_config/tests/test_keystone.py', 'os_cloud_config/keystone.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-cloud-config/commit/a2e5dda22b12f8131dc77749356921343e38a2a9', 'message': 'Port initialize() and friends to Keystone v2

Currently, everything that incubator does with Keystone is making
use of the v2 client, which means that the initialize() method to
set up keystone also needs to support that.

Change-Id: Ia09afab15abe06d24ff43988a05d1f102ba457c3
'}]
commit_message:
Port initialize() and friends to Keystone v2

Currently, everything that incubator does with Keystone is making
use of the v2 client, which means that the initialize() method to
set up keystone also needs to support that.

Change-Id: Ia09afab15abe06d24ff43988a05d1f102ba457c3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-cloud-config refs/changes/18/91518/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import keystoneclient.v2_0.client as ksclient _create_tenants(keystone) description='Owns users and tenants created by heat' description='Manages users and tenants created by heat', keystone.roles.grant(admin_role, user=heat_admin, domain=heat_domain) """Create Keystone v2 client for admin endpoint. admin_url = "http://%s:35357/v2.0" % host :param keystone: keystone v2 clientdef _create_tenants(keystone): """Create initial tenants in Keystone. :param keystone: keystone v2 client LOG.debug('Creating admin tenant.') keystone.tenants.create('admin', None) LOG.debug('Creating service tenant.') keystone.tenants.create('service', None) :param keystone: keystone v2 client admin_tenant = keystone.tenants.find(name='admin') admin_user = keystone.users.create('admin', email=admin_email, tenant_id=admin_tenant.id) LOG.debug('Granting admin role to admin user on admin tenant.') keystone.roles.add_user_role(admin_user, admin_role, admin_tenant)
deleted_lines: import keystoneclient.v3.client as ksclient _create_projects(keystone) description='Owns users and projects created by heat' description='Manages users and projects created by heat', keystone.roles.grant(admin_role, user=heat_admin, domain=heat_domain) """Create Keystone v3 client for admin endpoint. admin_url = "http://%s:35357/v3" % host :param keystone: keystone v3 clientdef _create_projects(keystone): """Create initial projects in Keystone. :param keystone: keystone v3 client LOG.debug('Creating admin project.') keystone.projects.create('admin', None) LOG.debug('Creating service project.') keystone.projects.create('service', None) :param keystone: keystone v3 client admin_project = keystone.projects.find(name='admin') admin_user = keystone.users.create('admin', email=admin_email, project=admin_project) LOG.debug('Granting admin role to admin user on admin project.') keystone.roles.grant(admin_role, user=admin_user, project=admin_project)

subject: Correct murano-agent reference to message headers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-02 23:46:43.000000000', 'files': ['python-agent/muranoagent/common/messaging/message.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano-agent/commit/a9bf46545502afb9991f7ffd65406797b79d1716', 'message': "Correct murano-agent reference to message headers

The python-murano agent refers to a 'header'
attribute when trying to extract the message
id from the list of headers.

The message object is of the class
kombu.transport.pyamqp.Message, which does not
have a 'header' attribute, but a 'headers'
attribute.

The reference needs to be corrected to 'headers'

Change-Id: Ibf470090e01d159cdfea13d142f6b712c649183a
Closes-Bug: #1315571
"}]
commit_message:
Correct murano-agent reference to message headers

The python-murano agent refers to a 'header'
attribute when trying to extract the message
id from the list of headers.

The message object is of the class
kombu.transport.pyamqp.Message, which does not
have a 'header' attribute, but a 'headers'
attribute.

The reference needs to be corrected to 'headers'

Change-Id: Ibf470090e01d159cdfea13d142f6b712c649183a
Closes-Bug: #1315571
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-agent refs/changes/24/91924/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.id = message_handle.headers.get('message_id')
deleted_lines: self.id = message_handle.header.get('message_id')

commit_message:
Fix H302 violations in unit tests

H302 violation is reported by flake8 when importing separated objects from
modules instead of importing the whole module.
e.g.   from package.module import function
       function()
is changed to
       from package import module
       module.function()

Change-Id: Ic6975f39c755ded54149a9c01fcdcfaf78c596fc
Partial-Bug: #1291032

commit_message:
Pass the user's token into build_app

- Don't use admin credentials to build the image,
  instead use the trust token.
- Don't try and source devstack's openrc as the enviroment
  is passed in.

Change-Id: I0897e383bfdb914c9e4e6c8cab572ec9b145b5d8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/39/91339/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ -z $1 ]] || [[ -z $2 ]] || [[ -z $3 ]]; then echo "Usage: build git_url appname base_image"if [[ -z $OS_AUTH_TOKEN ]]; then echo 'openstack credentials not passed via ENV.' exit 1APP_DIR=/opt/solum/apps/$OS_TENANT_ID/$APP
deleted_lines: if [[ -z $1 ]] || [[ -z $2 ]] || [[ -z $3 ]] || [[ -z $4 ]]; then echo "Usage: build git_url appname project_id base_image"TENANT=$1 shiftif [[ -z $OS_USERNAME ]]; then echo 'openstack credentials not passed via ENV. hunting for openrc.' [[ -f ./openrc ]] && . ./openrc [[ -f ~/devstack/openrc ]] && . ~/devstack/openrcAPP_DIR=/opt/solum/apps/$TENANT/$APP

Enable security_groups_basic_ops blocking tests

Check that bug 1252620 and bug 1112912 are fixed

commit_message:
Give a full path for glance verification

Give a specific directory so that it's clear that this is not a
subdirectory of the Image store (/var/lib/glance).

Also, remove the created directory at the end to make it clear that this
is a temporary download.

Change-Id: If42e5e891e728e7fb87318e29d88ede1376294b2
Closes-Bug: #1271018

commit_message:
Slight increase in testenv disk space

When building multiple overcloud control nodes the undercloud needs more
disk space for image handling. The current default of 30gb is very close
to this limit and causes spurious out of space failures. Increasing this
value to 40.

Change-Id: Ic515e176748bd4ef644188e7e30a35ed38c2c141

commit_message:
Fix status reason in events for deployment signals

When a signal is received and processed by a Resource, there could be an
event generated automatically. For such an event, Heat is supposed to
provide some useful message (including status_reason).  But currently,
the resource code can only process ceilometer alarms and watch rules,
for signals sent for a SoftwareDeployment resource, the signal is only
providing an string 'Unknown' as the status change reason.  This is
confusing when a user performs 'heat event-list stack'.

This patch adds an additional check (guess) whether the signal comes
from a SoftwareDeployment.  If that is the case, fill in the status
reason as 'deployment succeeded', or 'deployment failed (n)', where n is
the deploy_status_code that comes with the signal.

Closes-Bug: #1300679
Change-Id: Ic970a5dac923fffdcdd365983df58f4d338de849
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/65/84665/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-04 05:57:25.000000000', 'files': ['doc/common/samples/networking_auth.json', 'doc/common/samples/authentication.json', 'doc/common/samples/restrict_roles.json', 'doc/common/samples/restrict_roles2.json', 'doc/config-reference/compute/samples/cells-resp.json', 'doc/user-guide/samples/meta_data_ec2.json', 'doc/common/samples/server-scheduler-hints2.json', 'doc/common/samples/dashboard-nova_policy.json', 'doc/common/samples/list_metadata.json', 'doc/common/samples/server-scheduler-hints.json', 'doc/common/samples/server-scheduler-hints4.json', 'doc/common/samples/token.json', 'doc/user-guide/samples/meta_data.json', 'doc/common/samples/dashboard-keystone_policy.json', 'doc/common/samples/server-scheduler-hints3.json'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/37ad5d3ebe1a3e2fdf22b1e5e577f8ff4550e973', 'message': 'Make JSON files more readable

JSON formatting can be optimized for size or for readability. The JSON
files in openstack-manuals favor readability (for obvious reasons).
Unlike typical JSON formatted for reading (see Wikipedia article on
JSON, or Python's JSON output), however, the files have no space after
the name-separator, making them somewhat harder to read.

This changeset adds the missing space after the name-separator.

It also changes indenting from 3 to 4 spaces (matching our conventions
for Python and shell code).

The order of keys (which doesn't matter for the software parser) has
been preserved, because the order may be intentional (to help human
readers).

For instance:

   "uuid":"d8e02d56-2648-49a3-bf97-6be8f1204f38",

becomes:

    "uuid": "d8e02d56-2648-49a3-bf97-6be8f1204f38",

It also changes a few overly long empty sets. For instance:

   "volume:create":[

   ],

    becomes:

    "volume:create": [],

Change-Id: I559907e72578e6fb1a1a6895bd005ad9b22210d7
'}]
commit_message:
Make JSON files more readable

JSON formatting can be optimized for size or for readability. The JSON
files in openstack-manuals favor readability (for obvious reasons).
Unlike typical JSON formatted for reading (see Wikipedia article on
JSON, or Python's JSON output), however, the files have no space after
the name-separator, making them somewhat harder to read.

This changeset adds the missing space after the name-separator.

It also changes indenting from 3 to 4 spaces (matching our conventions
for Python and shell code).

The order of keys (which doesn't matter for the software parser) has
been preserved, because the order may be intentional (to help human
readers).

For instance:

   "uuid":"d8e02d56-2648-49a3-bf97-6be8f1204f38",

becomes:

    "uuid": "d8e02d56-2648-49a3-bf97-6be8f1204f38",

It also changes a few overly long empty sets. For instance:

   "volume:create":[

   ],

    becomes:

    "volume:create": [],

Change-Id: I559907e72578e6fb1a1a6895bd005ad9b22210d7

commit_message:
Remove redundant 'import testscenarios' from tests

In review [1], Angus added testscenarios support in BaseTestCase. So we don't
need to import the same anymore in other modules.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/91711/

Change-Id: I7883b68226dc20a5ce89426ad8259d69d8050531

commit_message:
Description mismatch in F20 hot

Parameter db_password & db_root_password description are not
correct. db_username should change to db_password.

Change-Id: I0e0a31152e1fac5fe75a21b647a031d8a6bbdb07

commit_message:
Optimize querying for security groups

In the check for all security groups on port belong to tenant,
add a filter to get security groups for the tenant which are in
common with the security groups of the port.

Change-Id: I66f31755525fca37f9dbce6fb43e475791f82495
Closes-Bug: #1315097

commit_message:
Pass executor via kwargs instead of config

Breaking change: moves from taking an executor
from configuration (it really is not configuration) and
instead takes that executor instead from the additional
kwargs which can be provided to a engine-specific type.

Change-Id: I475f33a63ebd08f6c20a16534423c8bc3502fa3f

commit_message:
Allow the WBE to use a preexisting executor

A worker task executor is a good candidate for reuse since
it maintains worker knowledge that is valuable to be retained
across engine runs (tasks on which workers for example). In order
for it to be reused we need a way for the WBE to be able to
receive and reuse a previously existing executor.

Change-Id: Ia9a8f4c544b74e12e2cbd6bd941945da1111499c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/49/90849/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ProxyTaskExecutor(TaskExecutorBase): """Proxies to another executor (allows for skipping starting and stopping the underlying executor, this can be useful to reuse existing executors). """ def __init__(self, executor, stop=True, start=True): self._executor = executor self._stop = stop self._start = start def execute_task(self, task, task_uuid, arguments, progress_callback=None): return self._executor.execute_task(task, task_uuid, arguments, progress_callback=progress_callback) def revert_task(self, task, task_uuid, arguments, result, failures, progress_callback=None): return self._executor.revert_task(task, task_uuid, arguments, result, failures, progress_callback=progress_callback) def wait_for_any(self, fs, timeout=None): return self._executor.wait_for_any(fs, timeout=timeout) def start(self): if self._start: self._executor.start() def stop(self): if self._stop: self._executor.stop()

subject: Add exception catch if Storwize/SVC driver failed when retyping
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-22 13:06:35.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/ibm/storwize_svc/__init__.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/ibm/storwize_svc/helpers.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/d17277d37d41072b113738d95c0a3bf3a6ab2549', 'message': 'Add exception catch if Storwize/SVC driver failed when

If adding a copy for a volume of Storwize/SVC which is under
migration, Storwize/SVC command will fail because the
number of the copies of the volume exceed the limit which
is 2.

Modifying the volume type when adding a copy for the volume,
Storwize/SVC driver will also fail, should add exception catch.

Also add exception catch when getting the volume from the database.
This change is necessary to enable resolving bug 1305550
(https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1305550 - Failed retype with
driver raised exception should set volume status to "error" ).

Change-Id: I1cf4b6606b5228c8adcb2bde21f345fa979bc13e
Closes-Bug: #1298201
(cherry picked from commit 24eb8234ff4b907b8c88f26fb0c427cb7a452140)
'}]
commit_message:
Add exception catch if Storwize/SVC driver failed when
retyping

If adding a copy for a volume of Storwize/SVC which is under
migration, Storwize/SVC command will fail because the
number of the copies of the volume exceed the limit which
is 2.

Modifying the volume type when adding a copy for the volume,
Storwize/SVC driver will also fail, should add exception catch.

Also add exception catch when getting the volume from the database.
This change is necessary to enable resolving bug 1305550
(https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1305550 - Failed retype with
driver raised exception should set volume status to "error" ).

commit_message:
Make default orchestration build_interval 10

It is possible that the Fedora 20 boot timeouts seen in bug #1297560
are caused by general load on the devstack server. To reduce the
load this change makes the build_interval 10 seconds instead of 1.

Change-Id: I19f654dcb108fb355f5780d4169b57ac52181667
Related-Bug: #1297560

deleted_lines: default=1,

starts

commit_message:
Add Storage Policy Support to Container Sync

Have container sync get its object ring from POLICIES now,
update tests to use policy index from container_info and pass
that along for use in ring selection.

Change-Id: If57d3b0ff8c395f21c81fda76458bc34fcb23257
Implements: blueprint storage-policies

commit_message:
Convert POLICIES to list for random.choice

python's random.choice is implemented by taking a random index into the length
of a list and selecting the item at that integer index.

POLICIES is not a list, but happened mostly fit the interface for
random.choice since it had a len and supported integer indexing, but would
fail if your storage policy index's had any gaps.

In python3 a dict's .values() method returns a view instead of a real list so
changing StoragePolicyCollections __iter__ method to return .values() instead
of .itervalues() wouldn't buy us much.  It seems better to just convert
POLICIES to a list and conform to the contract for random.choice.

Change-Id: Id72a025822ecb6c8fec6b7be377d58ce9cb8f7b5

commit_message:
TempURL: Fixed bug with \r or \n in disposition.

If an object had a \r or \n in its name, it would end up creating an
invalid HTTP Content-Disposition header. Reviewer consensus was to use
URL encoding.

Fixes bug 1306250

Change-Id: Ibccaaed5152b4d09d6aee4966a1982cc0a0da07d

subject: Modify the CLI output for 'task detailed'
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-23 21:39:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/021f3709fde2c40f87d01d73d4262ebffe6672e6', 'message': "Modify the CLI output for 'task detailed'

1. Join the 2 output tables (atomic actions & overall results) into one table.
   Format the float numbers to make the table more neat.

Before: http://paste.openstack.org/show/76847/
After:  http://paste.openstack.org/show/76848/

2. Do not use the PrettyTable lib directly, but use openstack.common.cliutils.

3. Remove the --no-aggregation parameter that previously allowed to switch
   between 2 modes of atomic action tables. Always show the 'default' atomic
   actions table and inroduce a new --iterations-data parameter, which makes
   Rally show the detailed information about iteration durations in a separate

commit_message:
Modify the CLI output for 'task detailed'

1. Join the 2 output tables (atomic actions & overall results) into one table.
   Format the float numbers to make the table more neat.

Before: http://paste.openstack.org/show/76847/
After:  http://paste.openstack.org/show/77630/

2. Do not use the PrettyTable lib directly, but use openstack.common.cliutils.

3. Remove the --no-aggregation parameter that previously allowed to switch
   between 2 modes of atomic action tables. Always show the 'default' atomic
   actions table and inroduce a new --iterations-data parameter, which makes
   Rally show the detailed information about iteration durations in a separate
   table below the main one.

Change-Id: I942b6d461e1e649f12ef0085ddd86677e8cbcee2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/41/89941/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from rally.openstack.common import cliutils as common_cliutilsfrom rally import utils as rutils @cliutils.args('--iterations-data', dest='iterations_data', help='print detailed results for each iteration') def detailed(self, task_id=None, iterations_data=False): :param iterations_data: print detailed results for each iteration def _print_iterations_data(raw): def _get_atomic_action_durations(raw): atomic_actions_names = [] atomic_actions_names.append(a["action"]) break result = {} for atomic_action in atomic_actions_names: result[atomic_action] = utils.get_durations( raw, lambda r: next(a["duration"] for a in r["atomic_actions"] if a["action"] == atomic_action), lambda r: any((a["action"] == atomic_action) for a in r["atomic_actions"])) return result def _pretty_float_formatter(field): def _formatter(obj): value = getattr(obj, field) if value: return "%.3f" % value else: return "n/a" return _formatter table_cols = ["action", "min", "avg", "max", "percentile_90", "percentile_95", "success", "count"] float_cols = ["min", "avg", "max", "percentile_90", "percentile_95"] formatters = dict(zip(float_cols, [_pretty_float_formatter(col) for col in float_cols])) table_rows = [] action_durations = _get_atomic_action_durations(raw) actions_list = action_durations.keys() action_durations["total"] = utils.get_durations( raw, lambda x: x["duration"], lambda r: not r["error"]) actions_list.append("total") for action in actions_list: durations = action_durations[action] if durations: data = [action, min(durations), utils.avg(durations), max(durations), utils.percentile(durations, 0.90), utils.percentile(durations, 0.95), "%.1f%%" % (len(durations) * 100.0 / len(raw)), len(raw)] else: data = [action, None, None, None, None, None, 0, len(raw)] table_rows.append(rutils.Struct(dict(zip(table_cols, data)))) common_cliutils.print_list(table_rows, fields=table_cols, formatters=formatters) if iterations_data: _print_iterations_data(raw)
deleted_lines: import collections @cliutils.args('--no-aggregation', dest='no_aggregation', help='do not aggregate atomic operation results') def detailed(self, task_id=None, no_aggregation=False): :param no_aggregation: do not aggregate atomic operations def _print_atomic_actions_no_aggregation(raw): def _print_atomic_actions_aggregation(raw): aduration_merged = [] aduration_merged.append(a) durations_by_action = collections.defaultdict(list) for at in aduration_merged: durations_by_action[at['action']].append(at['duration']) if durations_by_action: atomic_action_table = prettytable.PrettyTable( ['action', 'count', 'max (sec)', 'avg (sec)', 'min (sec)', '90 percentile', '95 percentile']) for k, v in durations_by_action.iteritems(): atomic_action_table.add_row([k, len(v), max(v), utils.avg(v), min(v), utils.percentile(v, 0.90), utils.percentile(v, 0.95)]) print(atomic_action_table) print() def _print_atomic_actions(raw): if no_aggregation: _print_atomic_actions_no_aggregation(raw) else: _print_atomic_actions_aggregation(raw) _print_atomic_actions(result["data"]["raw"]) durations = utils.get_durations(raw, lambda x: x['duration'], lambda r: not r['error']) table = prettytable.PrettyTable(["max (sec)", "avg (sec)", "min (sec)", "90 pecentile", "95 percentile", "success/total", "total times"]) if durations: table.add_row([max(durations), utils.avg(durations), min(durations), utils.percentile(durations, 0.90), utils.percentile(durations, 0.95), float(len(durations)) / len(raw), len(raw)]) else: table.add_row(['n/a', 'n/a', 'n/a', 'n/a', 'n/a', 0, len(raw)]) print(table)

Instead of linking to other topics (which then uses
the name of those topics as the link name) define a

commit_message:
Adjust doc linking

Instead of linking to other topics (which then uses
the name of those topics as the link name) define a
name that makes more sense for the inline usage and
retain the link to the document using wording that
fits the surronding text.

Also adjust the futures/executor links to point to the
external links documenting these features.

Change-Id: I5a89e2f747dfec2505947f25c124b157271c07cf

added_lines: That includes all the information that :doc:`atoms <atoms>` (e.g. tasks) in the flow need when they are executed, and all the information task produces (via serializable task results). A developer who implements tasks or flows can specify what arguments a task accepts and what result it returns in several ways. This document will help you understand what those ways are and how to use those ways to accomplish your desired usage pattern.
deleted_lines: That includes all the information that atoms (e.g. tasks) in the flow need when they are executed, and all the information task produces (via serializable task results). A developer who implements tasks or flows can specify what arguments a task accepts and what result it returns in several ways. This document will help you understand what those ways are and how to use those ways to accomplish your desired TaskFlow usage pattern.

subject: Add support for ephemeral disk to ironic
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-01 15:40:48.000000000', 'files': ['lib/ironic'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/3e4612b2f7185a4cf4ca21ac8e4dce302a774373', 'message': 'Add support for ephemeral disk to ironic

Add a new variable, IRONIC_VM_EPHEMERAL_DISK, to specify the size

Change-Id: Ia8a8ef364a85fc803b93fb936212de0894a19bd8

commit_message:
Add support for ephemeral disk to ironic

Add a new variable, IRONIC_VM_EPHEMERAL_DISK, to specify the size
of the ephemeral disk. Default will be zero to match the current
behavior.

Change-Id: Ia8a8ef364a85fc803b93fb936212de0894a19bd8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/89/91589/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: IRONIC_VM_EPHEMERAL_DISK=${IRONIC_VM_EPHEMERAL_DISK:-0} adjusted_disk=$(($IRONIC_VM_SPECS_DISK - $IRONIC_VM_EPHEMERAL_DISK)) nova flavor-create --ephemeral $IRONIC_VM_EPHEMERAL_DISK baremetal auto $IRONIC_VM_SPECS_RAM $adjusted_disk $IRONIC_VM_SPECS_CPU
deleted_lines: nova flavor-create baremetal auto $IRONIC_VM_SPECS_RAM $IRONIC_VM_SPECS_DISK $IRONIC_VM_SPECS_CPU

commit_message:
Add CPU CQM (Cache Qos Monitoring) management

Intel's new CPUs introduce Cache QoS Monitoring (CQM) allows an Operating System,
Hypervisor or similar system management agent to determine the usage of cache
by applications running on the platform. The initial implementation is directed
at last level cache (LLC) monitoring. So this can be used to monitor the
instance's cache.

Add the RMID resouce plugin to manager which instance can be monitored
the cache.

Change-Id: I267e10d333e4b6a5c1664ce231a70f93b7acada8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/86/91986/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================= Add CPU CQM (Cache Qos Monitoring) management ============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/cache-qos-monitoring CQM:Enables monitoring of cache occupancy on a per-thread (via RMID) basis. RMID : The ID of the application or thread on a core as specified by the OS/VMM. This ID is provided by the OS/VMM, and used by the platform to tag and monitor events such as cache occupancy. Intel's new CPUs introduce Cache QoS Monitoring (CQM) allows an Operating System, Hypervisor or similar system management agent to determine the usage of cache by applications running on the platform. The initial implementation is directed at last level cache (LLC) monitoring. We want to add this new feature into OpenStack in this Blueprint. And this need kernel and xen to support the CQM feature. So We will do some work in kernel, xen, libvirt, xenapi and OpenStack. When get the cache data, should via a RMID, but the total RMID numbers of different platforms are differents. So we want to add a RMID managerment in Nova. Problem description =================== The main use case is to monitor the cache of each intstance. The user can enable the CQM function in the Nova and get the instance's 'cache data from Ceilometer agent[3]. #TBD Proposed change =============== This blueprints dependency on Paul Murray's blueprint[1]. Add a RMID resource plugin to manager the RMID resource. #TBD Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- The blueprint used the extra_resources field in the compute node table to communicate the resource tracking information. This field was added to the database in Icehouse-2 but has not yet been used. The extra_specs field will be added to the instances table in Paul Murray's blueprint[1]. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- The plugins will be configured in the blueprint extensible-resource-tracking ways. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: shuangtai-tian qiaowei-ren Work Items ---------- * Add the RMID resource plugin to resource tracker * Add the RMID resource consumer plubin to the host manager * Add extra_specs to instance_system_metadata Dependencies ============ *This blueprint dependency on extensible-resource-tracking https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/extensible-resource-tracking *Also dependecy on the new version of kernel, xen, libvirt and xenapi. #TBD Testing ======= Unit tests are sufficient to cover feature changes. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== [1]https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/extensible-resource-tracking [2]https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/cache-qos-monitoring [3]https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/cache-qos-monitoring

subject: Fix listing of endpoints for a token
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-04 13:25:47.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/v2_0/tokens.py', 'keystoneclient/v2_0/endpoints.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/fd8bf05ba601313ffc458638b92e2d7d3cd4bb93', 'message': 'Fix listing of endpoints for a token

The client is currently failing to list endpoints for a token because it is looking for a non-existing token key in the response from Keystone:

def endpoints(self, token):
    return self._get(/tokens/%s/endpoints % base.getid(token), token)

It needs to be changed to look for the endpoints key instead and parse its value correctly.

Change-Id: I38c606c9cc7dcd829a5e94fd48c2a84d6f8d658a
Closes-Bug: #1315798
'}]
commit_message:
Fix listing of endpoints for a token

The client is currently failing to list endpoints for a token because it is looking for a non-existing token key in the response from Keystone:

def endpoints(self, token):
    return self._get(/tokens/%s/endpoints % base.getid(token), token)

It needs to be changed to look for the endpoints key instead and parse its value correctly.

Change-Id: I38c606c9cc7dcd829a5e94fd48c2a84d6f8d658a
Closes-Bug: #1315798
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/09/92009/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def list(self, token=None): if token: return self._list('/tokens/%s/endpoints' % base.getid(token), 'endpoints') else: return self._list('/endpoints', 'endpoints')
deleted_lines: def list(self): """List all available endpoints.""" return self._list('/endpoints', 'endpoints')

global variables introduced by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/86567/

Change-Id: I76d8e8c9b9ac558f31cb3e22a936efbebff5b9a3

commit_message:
Configure VPN when upgrading from Icehouse

There was a change in devstack how VPNaaS agent is started. It uses some
global variables introduced by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/86567/

Closes-Bug: #1313791
Change-Id: I76d8e8c9b9ac558f31cb3e22a936efbebff5b9a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/grenade refs/changes/85/90785/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env bash # ``upgrade-neutron`` configure_neutron_upgrade(){ XTRACE=$(set +o | grep xtrace) set -o xtrace if is_service_enabled q-vpn; then Q_VPN_CONF_FILE=$NEUTRON_CONF_DIR/vpn_agent.ini cp $NEUTRON_DIR/etc/vpn_agent.ini $Q_VPN_CONF_FILE VPN_CONF_FILES="--config-file $NEUTRON_CONF --config-file=$Q_L3_CONF_FILE --config-file=$Q_VPN_CONF_FILE" for cfg_file in ${Q_VPN_EXTRA_CONF_FILES[@]}; do VPN_CONF_FILES+=" --config-file $cfg_file" done fi $XTRACE }

subject: Add mock.patch.stopall() to rally test cleanup
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-30 18:49:59.000000000', 'files': ['tests/test.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/9978d0855e0dda503c15e60d8e3bd2b3ac810f59', 'message': 'Add mock.patch.stopall() to rally test cleanup

* using stopall() to stop patches avoids race conditions
  that might arise when mock state is not cleaned up
  between test cases
* use of stopall() from test case cleanup is recommended
  when applying patches as part setUp()

Change-Id: I7918cc8c7c96a25ae874ea8bede93719d6baa634
'}]
commit_message:
Add mock.patch.stopall() to rally test cleanup

* using stopall() to stop patches avoids race conditions
  that might arise when mock state is not cleaned up
  between test cases
* use of stopall() from test case cleanup is recommended
  when applying patches as part setUp()

Change-Id: I7918cc8c7c96a25ae874ea8bede93719d6baa634
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/35/91435/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import mock def setUp(self): super(TestCase, self).setUp() self.addCleanup(mock.patch.stopall)
deleted_lines: pass

commit_message:
Use escapejs filter on JavaScript strings

The escapejs filter will correctly escape single quotes from JavaScript
strings which may otherwise trigger syntax errors. In this case, the
issue was visible using the French translation.

Also removed a trailing paranthesis coming out of nowhere.

Change-Id: I25001815e17be5afa8eb28cc28c5423e3dcd973c
Closes-Bug: #1311047
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/34/89534/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: some_disabled_msg = '{{_("Some flavors not meeting minimum image requirements have been disabled.")}}'; all_disabled_msg = '{{_("No flavors meet minimum criteria for selected image.")}})';

Use common entities file

Instead of declaring entities separately for each file, include the file
common/entities/openstack.ent.

commit_message:
Add protection for Query deadlock in sqlalchemy

The function '@_wrap_db_error' and '@retry_on_dead_lock',
is only available for session deadlock(query/flush/execute).

But it doesn't cover some 'Query' actions.
So, we need to add the same protction for 'all()' in sqlalchemy.

Change-Id: I7ec6420a8141261dddff9aaa9a62bf14dbf45875
Closes-Bug: #1283987

LOG.exception(_LE(msg)) raise TypeError(msg) _raise_if_db_connection_lost(e, bind) _raise_if_deadlock_error(e, engine_name) _raise_if_duplicate_entry_error(e, engine_name)

commit_message:
Add _wrap_db_error support for postgresql

The original "_wrap_db_error" function is only available for mysql.
We need to add support for postgresql.

The deadlock exception thrown from postgresql is TransactionRollbackError,
it's not the same with "OperationalError" thrown from mysql,
and isn't included in sqlalchemy. So, the base exception need to be
catched.

Change-Id: I82c06598b1c95eb58c218d61070ffd443061458c
Closes-Bug: #1270725

added_lines:
"POT-Creation-Date: 2014-05-04 03:02+0000
" "PO-Revision-Date: 2014-05-03 13:30+0000
" "Last-Translator: Tomoyuki KATO <tomo@dream.daynight.jp>
"msgstr "下記の設定を RabbitMQ のシステム設定ファイルに追加します。通常、<filename>/etc/rabbitmq/rabbitmq.config</filename> に保存されています。"msgstr "<literal>tcp_listeners</literal> オプションを <literal>[]</literal> に指定し、非 SSL ポートの接続を受け付けない設定にしていることに注意してください。 <literal>ssl_listeners</literal> オプションはサービスの管理ネットワークのみ受け付けるよう限定すべきです。"msgstr "導入前に、キューサーバが使用する SSL ライブラリについて考慮します。Qpid はMozilla の NSS ライブラリを、RabbitMQ は OpenSSL を使う Erlang の SSL モジュールを用いています。"msgstr "RabbitMQ サーバで、デフォルトの <literal>guest</literal> ユーザを削除します。"msgstr "IP ADDRESS OF SERVER"msgstr "クォータは、テナントに対して利用可能なネットワークリソース数を制限する機能を提供します。全てのテナントに対してデフォルトのクォータを強制する事が出来ます。<filename>/etc/neutron/neutron.conf</filename> にクォータに関するこれらのオプションがあります。"msgstr "OpenStack Networking はまた、クォータ拡張 API 経由で、テナント単位のクォータをサポートしています。テナント単位クォータを有効にするためには、<filename>neutron.conf</filename> 中の <literal>quota_driver</literal> を設定する必要があります。"

commit_message:
Add _wrap_db_error support for postgresql

The original "_wrap_db_error" function is only available for mysql.
We need to add support for postgresql.

The deadlock exception thrown from postgresql is TransactionRollbackError,
it's not the same with "OperationalError" thrown from mysql,
and isn't included in sqlalchemy. So, the base exception need to be
catched.

Change-Id: I6bb49a1d616fe7477b253fadbcc4234b93c51b8d
Closes-Bug: #1270725
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db refs/changes/79/91979/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Medium-level docs on engines

Describe why engines exist and also describe at a
somewhat lower-level how an action engine goes
through its various stages when executing
and what each stages high-level goal is (and how it
is performed).

Change-Id: I79c4b90047826fb2c9f33da75044a9cb42cfe47d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/98/91898/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: **Execution:** When an engine beings to execute (see :doc:`engine <engines>` for more of the details about how an engine goes about this process) it will examine any previously existing :py:class:`~taskflow.persistence.logbook.AtomDetail` objects to see if they can be used for resuming; see :doc:`resumption <resumption>` for more details on this subject. For atoms which have not finished (or did not finish correctly from a previous run) they will begin executing only after any dependent inputs are ready. This is done by analyzing the execution graph and looking at predecessor :py:class:`~taskflow.persistence.logbook.AtomDetail`
deleted_lines: **Execution:** When an engine beings to execute it will examine any previously existing :py:class:`~taskflow.persistence.logbook.AtomDetail` objects to see if they can be used for resuming; see :doc:`resumption <resumption>` for more details on this subject. For atoms which have not finished (or did not finish correctly from a previous run) they will begin executing only after any dependent inputs are ready. This is done by analyzing the execution graph and looking at predecessor :py:class:`~taskflow.persistence.logbook.AtomDetail`

commit_message:
Publish only for trunk

Publish documents only for trunk.

This patch needs to go in before we branch for stable. Once branched,
the stable/icehouse branch should be changed again to get a
publishdocs section that only contains the following line for publishdocs:
openstack-doc-test --check-build --publish --only-book install-guide --only-book config-reference

Change-Id: Ibb2f7ef3917801f158896308f1d5b5ba350acf5c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/71/91971/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ## Commands for master: ## Commands for stable/icehouse only: # openstack-doc-test --check-build --publish --only-book install-guide --only-book config-reference
deleted_lines: # Publish install-guide and config-reference to /icehouse # TODO(jaegerandi): Remove these lines before we branch off an # icehouse branch. cp -a publish-docs/trunk publish-docs/icehouse # Replace links to /trunk with links to /icehouse/ # This needs bash so that tox does not interpret the * bash -c "sed -i -e 's|/trunk/|/icehouse/|g' publish-docs/icehouse/*/atom.xml publish-docs/icehouse/*/*/*/atom.xml publish-docs/icehouse/*/*.html publish-docs/icehouse/*/*/*/*/*.html publish-docs/icehouse/*/*/*/*.html publish-docs/icehouse/*/*/*.html publish-docs/icehouse/*/*.html"

commit_message:
check for Mirantis OCF scripts in failover test

Heartbeat OCF scripts were replaced with Mirantis versions, looking for
old names generates false positives in failover test.

Change-Id: I29647ea95544ea5c57fb88ed04049d28f5f6d420
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/90/90490/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: re.search('vip__management_old\s+\(ocf::mirantis:ns_IPaddr2\):' re.search('vip__public_old\s+\(ocf::mirantis:ns_IPaddr2\):'
deleted_lines: re.search('vip__management_old\s+\(ocf::heartbeat:IPaddr2\):' re.search('vip__public_old\s+\(ocf::heartbeat:IPaddr2\):'

commit_message:
moved deploy docs to user guide, added headers between screen shots

This moves this information to the User Guide and adds space
and a width: specification to the screen shots so they can be
viewed.  It does not address content issues with this material.

The material moved here includes:
- A numbered and tabled summary of the deployment process from pre-install
- Deployment screen shots from pre-install; note that fuel-settings had to
  be broken up because it size caused build errors
  TODO:(Meg McRoberts) add annotations to these screen shots, with xrefs to
     other sections in the doc that provides supporting information
- NIC bonding (UI) info from the OVS section in reference-architecture
- Info about starting and stopping the deployment from install-guide

Closes-Bug: 1292024
Change-Id: I37ac52597c02e7c8f05ecfb9fbbb54c2cd103802
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/10/91710/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #. Download the Fuel ISO from the `Mirantis web-site <http://software.mirantis.com/>`_. #. Mount or burn the ISO. #. Power on your machine.#. Optionally, configure the IP address, default gateway, and DNS server by#. Optionally, set the ``showmenu`` property to **Yes** to open the extendedWhen Fuel is installed, you can follow the instructions in :ref:`deploy-environment-ug` to deploy a new Mirantis OpenStack environment. Booting the ISO image --------------------- :width: 70% Editing grub command line ------------------------- .. image:: /_images/grub-screen.png :width: 70%
deleted_lines: 1. Download the Fuel ISO from the `Mirantis web-site <http://software.mirantis.com/>`_. 2. Mount or burn the ISO. 3. Power on your machine.4. Optionally, configure the IP address, default gateway, and DNS server by5. Optionally, set the ``showmenu`` property to **Yes** to open the extended6. After Fuel completes the installation, point your browser to default Fuel UI URL: `http://10.20.0.2:8000 <http://10.20.0.2:8000>`__. 7. Alternatively, point your browser to the IP address and port number that you specified. 8. In the Fuel UI, create a new OpenStack environment. 9. Configure the network settings using the address plan. 10. Verify the network configuration by clicking **Verify Networks**. 11. In the **Settings** tab, modify additional options: * Access * OpenStack Components * Hypervisor type * Scheduler driver * Syslog * Storage 12. Assign a role for each node server. 13. Optionally, associate NICs with the OpenStack networks: 1. Select the nodes. 2. Click **Configure Interfaces**. 3. Drag and drop the appropriate networks onto the physical interfaces. 4. Click **Apply**. 14. Click **Deploy Changes**. Depending on your environment deployment of Mirantis OpenStack may take some time. After you deployed Mirantis OpenStack, verify the configuration by running the tests from the **Health Check** tab. .. image:: /_images/grub-screen.png :align: center Booting the ISO image. Editing grub command line. .. image:: /_images/fuel-wizard.png Create a new environment. .. image:: /_images/fuel-network-settings.png :align: center Network settings page. .. image:: /_images/fuel-settings.png :align: center Settings page. .. image:: /_images/fuel-nodes.png :align: center Add nodes to environment. .. image:: /_images/fuel-nodes-selected.png :align: center Select discovered nodes. .. image:: /_images/fuel-node-network.png :align: center Node's network settings. .. seealso:: :ref:`Installation Guide<install-guide>`

commit_message:
reorganized Sahara information

This divides the information into:
- Pre-Install Guide (planning information)
- User Guide (how to deploy; will be after instructions to deploy Mirantis OpenStack
- Operations Guide (advanced usage info)

Change-Id: I89fca5a6f3a17a7326cbbf599fb590c1705887a5

commit_message:
Improve help strings for radware LbaaS driver

Make strings consistent with what we use elsewhere:
* Capitalize first word
* End with "."
* Improve wording and spelling

Partial-Bug: #1315111
Change-Id: Ic378aa7e4f936c3f3da0a23598620c3b978cbf45

commit_message:
Add docs for the worker based engine (WBE)

Begin to rework the twiki docs into a developer doc,
moving items from the twiki to rst and adjusting examples
to make a unified place where the worker model can be
documented.

Change-Id: I43ed828be33351b9fb6606317011e7204f61a136
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/34/90834/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: For more information, please see :doc:`workers <workers>` for more details on how the worker based engine operates (and the design decisions behind it)... _blueprint page: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/taskflow?searchtext=wbe
deleted_lines: This is engine that schedules tasks to **workers** -- separate processes dedicated for certain tasks execution, possibly running on other machines, connected via `amqp <http://www.amqp.org/>`_ (or other supported `kombu <http://kombu.readthedocs.org/>`_ transports). For more information, please see `wiki page`_ for more details on how the worker based engine operates... _wiki page: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/TaskFlow/Worker-based_Engine .. _blueprint page: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/taskflow

subject: Ensure neutron configuration files are cleaned by clean.sh
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-01 12:18:10.000000000', 'files': ['clean.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/b00e4181a8da9eabe0951c064898089c8ed1e8b8', 'message': 'Ensure neutron configuration files are cleaned by clean.sh

Add the /etc/neutron directory to the list of directories
that are deleted.

Change-Id: Ia560179a3cf121f8d09a0c10c8b68375fdd13be7
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure neutron configuration files are cleaned by clean.sh

Add the /etc/neutron directory to the list of directories
that are deleted.

Change-Id: Ia560179a3cf121f8d09a0c10c8b68375fdd13be7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/50/91550/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo rm -rf /etc/keystone /etc/glance /etc/nova /etc/cinder /etc/swift /etc/heat /etc/neutron
deleted_lines: sudo rm -rf /etc/keystone /etc/glance /etc/nova /etc/cinder /etc/swift /etc/heat

commit_message:
Update help strings for cinder client

Make text consistent and clear.
Add periods to end of sentences.
Adjust test suite for change

Closes-Bug: #1275881

Change-Id: I1dfde51636e8dc4b42e4c4810c27c1c4ac513d82

commit_message:
Fix cache configuration checks

There were two different checks to see if a cache region was already
configured with a backend. Both were changed to use the
Region.is_configured property.

The initial reason for this change was that the hasattr approach in the
test fixture was causing some issues in Python 3. For some reason it was
forcing the __get__ lookup on the descriptor and Python 2 did not.

bp python3

Change-Id: I409656f5ede08160cc68d48e7a3a636328e3e9a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/52/84052/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not region.is_configured:
deleted_lines: if 'backend' not in region.__dict__:

commit_message:
setUp must be called on a fixture's parent first

There is some odd behavior when a fixture's setUp fails before it has a
change to call the parent's setUp. It causes an error in the error
handling and the original exception is lost. The bug has been reported
upstream:
  https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-fixtures/+bug/1299502

Change-Id: I27cbfbe2c8ae34e72950361f8d0d7d8d3e249f8c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/51/84051/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: super(Cache, self).setUp()
deleted_lines: super(Cache, self).setUp()

subject: First real Python 3 tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-28 17:22:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/e5fe0c23837ceba4ee6e0d1cc2e13affaf0e099f', 'message': "First real Python 3 tests

The goal of this changeset is to enable at least some of the tests to be
run under Python3. Even if we can't get them all to run initially it's
important that we start seeing the changes from bp keystone-py3kcompat.
Also it's important that we are checking for regressions. If we do all
this Python 3 work, but don't have automated tests in place we may
inadvertantly undo that work.

In this initial changeset I had to do some not nice things to get this
to work.

First I had to switch to using the nose test runner. testr seems to be
much more aggressive about importing everything, even when you are not
going to run the test module. This idea came from oslo. Once we have
full Python 3 support we can go back to testr.

Then I had to mock out some of the libraries that don't work on Python
3. This is unfortunate, but had to be done because keystone.test.core
indirectly imports a significant amount of the codebase.

bp python3

Change-Id: I6dd0d1b84380c4c386f70b72cdfcdf9b744c755f

commit_message:
First real Python 3 tests

The goal of this changeset is to enable at least some of the tests to be
run under Python3. Even if we can't get them all to run initially it's
important that we start seeing the changes from bp keystone-py3kcompat.
Also it's important that we are checking for regressions. If we do all
this Python 3 work, but don't have automated tests in place we may
inadvertantly undo that work.

In this initial changeset I had to do some not nice things to get this
to work.

First I had to switch to using the nose test runner. testr seems to be
much more aggressive about importing everything, even when you are not
going to run the test module. This idea came from oslo. Once we have
full Python 3 support we can go back to testr.

Then I had to mock out some of the libraries that don't work on Python
3. This is unfortunate, but had to be done because keystone.test.core
indirectly imports a significant amount of the codebase.

bp python3

Change-Id: I6dd0d1b84380c4c386f70b72cdfcdf9b744c755f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/34/83834/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: nose commands = nosetests \ keystone/tests/test_singular_plural.py \ keystone/tests/test_injection.py \ keystone/tests/test_cache_backend_mongo.py \ keystone/tests/test_injection.py \ keystone/tests/unit
deleted_lines: commands = python -c "import sys; print('hello from Python', sys.version_info)"

commit_message:
Pass unresolved template to Resource.update()

Previously the 'after' template passed to Resource.update() was completely
resolved. This led to an odd situation where the contents of a resource's
template snippet were either unresolved (but parsed) or resolved depending
on whether the resource had been updated or not. Resolve (ha!) this
discrepancy by passing a version of the template with the intrinsic
functions unresolved.

Change-Id: I8c11cdc3c28661db689b416833bde34cea12d98a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/67/89967/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: tmpl_diff = self.update_template_diff(after, before)

commit_message:
Add noqa support to no_setupclass_for_unit_tests

This commit adds support for using noqa with the T105 hacking check.
This is need to unit test the _find_caller() utility with setupClass
in the call stack.

Change-Id: I5c1a07d019b79b082cb895a17364f7e7cb2f08fe

commit_message:
LBaaS: Set correct nullable parameter for agent_id

Corrected the following model according to database
content:
 - NOT NULL for PoolLoadbalancerAgentBinding agent_id;

Partial-bug: #1296282

Change-Id: I1f11ec2e8f4c16f58dd8d4e6429e46eaedaec945

commit_message:
Autoscaling: compare fully-resolved templates

The Resource.t snippet is a parsed but unresolved template snippet. In
practice there should be no intrinsic functions included to resolve at the
moment, but in principle we should do comparisons on the fully-resolved
result.

Change-Id: I12d2e7c8282ddfbb7cca4930ef557ce3856a88b5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/65/89965/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def serialize_template(t): return json.dumps(function.resolve(t), sort_keys=True)
deleted_lines: import functools serialize_template = functools.partial(json.dumps, sort_keys=True)

subject: Remove unused arguments
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-23 13:32:03.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/common/rest_client.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/aede38086ff3eaa174ce93996f40b95b49c142b1', 'message': 'Remove unused arguments

The "response_checker" method has unused arguments ("url", "headers", "body").
So method does not need them and we can remove them.

Change-Id: I8b3a25513693e6a950fc44a8da5ae9549c13a23d
'}]
commit_message:
Remove unused arguments

The "response_checker" method has unused arguments ("url", "headers", "body").
So method does not need them and we can remove them.

Change-Id: I8b3a25513693e6a950fc44a8da5ae9549c13a23d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/35/89835/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def response_checker(self, method, resp, resp_body): self.response_checker(method, resp, resp_body)
deleted_lines: def response_checker(self, method, url, headers, body, resp, resp_body): self.response_checker(method, url, req_headers, req_body, resp, resp_body)

subject: Add a common class for Nova v2/v3 API tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-05 09:04:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/4b86823a60735d50373f82abc3b4ba5d687b3b55', 'message': 'Add a common class for Nova v2/v3 API tests

Now there is a lot of copy&paste test code for Nova v2/v3 API tests.
In addition, we need to add many checks for API test coverage.
As the result, we should apply the same changes to v2 and v3 tests.

For improving the maintenancebility, this patch adds a common class
to share it between v2 and v3 tests. In addition, this patch applies
this class to test_availability_zone of v2 and v3 as a sample.

After applying this class to all Nova API tests, we will be able to
remove current BaseV2ComputeTest and BaseV3ComputeTest classes.

Change-Id: I4f9c3f58c37fc459976c2e7dc36bfc90f5add3f5
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-03-05 09:27:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/3205eee884d1c5723307052de0eea3e445dfc802', 'message': 'Add a common class for Nova v2/v3 API tests

In addition, we need to add many checks for API test coverage.
As the result, we should apply the same changes to v2 and v3 tests.

For improving the maintenancebility, this patch adds a common class
to share it between v2 and v3 tests. In addition, this patch applies
this class to test_availability_zone of v2 and v3 as a sample.

After applying this class to all Nova API tests, we will be able to
remove current BaseV2ComputeTest and BaseV3ComputeTest classes.

Change-Id: I4f9c3f58c37fc459976c2e7dc36bfc90f5add3f5
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-03-05 11:29:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/7cff6031ea8de2d5be6d00cb0217ae668f4e3dfc', 'message': 'Add a common class for Nova v2/v3 API tests

For improving the maintenancebility, this patch adds a common class

Change-Id: I4f9c3f58c37fc459976c2e7dc36bfc90f5add3f5
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2014-03-10 00:11:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/49a975f880fa204c441f3bbfbcd54aff3f15f0f8', 'message': 'Add a common class for Nova v2/v3 API tests

Now there is a lot of copy&paste test code for Nova v2/v3 API tests.
In addition, we need to add many checks for API test coverage.

commit_message:
Add a common class for Nova v2/v3 API tests

Now there is a lot of copy&paste test code for Nova v2/v3 API tests.
In addition, we need to add many checks for API test coverage.
As the result, we should apply the same changes to v2 and v3 tests.

For improving the maintenance, this patch changes a base class to
share it between v2 and v3 tests. The existing BaseV2ComputeTest and
BaseV3ComputeTest inheritate from it now, and we will replace each
API test with a base class directly. As a sample, this patch applies
this class to test_availability_zone of v2 and v3.

This patch changes the test directory structure like:
 * tempest/api/compute/ : common test files like this test class
 * tempest/api/compute/v2/ : v2 API specific test files
 * tempest/api/compute/v3/ : v3 API specific test files

After applying this class to all Nova API tests, we will be able to
remove current BaseV2ComputeTest and BaseV3ComputeTest classes.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-test-inheritance

Change-Id: I4f9c3f58c37fc459976c2e7dc36bfc90f5add3f5

All associated " "data and resources are kept; however, anything still in memory is not " "retained. You can restore a shelved instance by using the " "unshelve action. commit_message:
Remove conductor usage from add_instance_fault_from_exc()

This makes add_instance_fault_from_exc() use the InstanceFault
object instead of a raw conductor call. This is actually a
minor change except that all callers of this method must now
stop passing the conductor API, and tests must return something
valid from the mocked call.

Related to blueprint virt-objects-juno

Change-Id: I49b17c1ef3d14fd36f016c37d88287e62126bf68
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/36/91136/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.objects import instance_fault as instance_fault_objdef add_instance_fault_from_exc(context, instance, fault, exc_info=None): fault_obj = instance_fault_obj.InstanceFault(context=context) fault_obj.host = CONF.host fault_obj.instance_uuid = instance['uuid'] fault_obj.update(exception_to_dict(fault)) code = fault_obj.code fault_obj.details = _get_fault_details(exc_info, code) fault_obj.create()
deleted_lines: def add_instance_fault_from_exc(context, conductor, instance, fault, exc_info=None): fault_dict = exception_to_dict(fault) code = fault_dict["code"] details = _get_fault_details(exc_info, code) values = { 'instance_uuid': instance['uuid'], 'code': code, 'message': fault_dict["message"], 'details': details, 'host': CONF.host } conductor.instance_fault_create(context, values)

commit_message:
Separate common 'start_up' definition from v2 schema

Tempest contains API schema definitions for response checks of Nova
v2/v3 APIs. On hosts 'start_up' API, the v3 definition refers to v2
one. However, we need to avoid this kind of dependency because we will
need to change v3 definition due to this dependency when removing v2
tests.

This patch separates common 'start_up' definition from v2 schema and
moves it to common schema file.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-attribute-test

Change-Id: If4291fcb6617b00a67066e3869deaf5a8a53f526
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/98/91498/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add a response header validation

Nova API sometimes returns important information in a response header,
and Tempest needs to check it for keeping the backward compatibility.
This patch adds the check for "create a server snapshot" API as the
sample.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-attribute-test

Change-Id: I2441147ee050e7b818906aaa754dcec4480d8c18

commit_message:
Medium-level docs on how an action engine executes

Describe at a somewhat lower-level how an action
engine goes through its various stages when executing
and what each stages high-level goal is (and how it
is performed).

Change-Id: Idfb8b7fcbf912ea7e95157f407b22f19cffa9cca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/27/91927/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: How they run ============ To provide a peek into the general process that a engine goes through when running lets break it apart a little and describe what one of the engine types does while executing (for this we will look into the :py:class:`~taskflow.engines.action_engine.engine.ActionEngine`). Creation -------- The first thing that occurs is that the user creates an engine for a given flow, providing a flow detail (where results will be saved into a provided :doc:`persistence <persistence>` backend). The engine at this point now will have references to your flow and backends and other internal variables are setup. Compiling --------- During this stage the flow will be converted into an internal graph representation using the the flow utilities provided in taskflow that convert the flow objects and contained tasks into a `networkx`_ directed graph that contains the equivalent tasks defined in the flow and any nested as well as the constraints that are created by the usage of the different flow patterns. This graph is then what will be analyzed & traversed during the engines execution. At this point a few helper classes are also created and saved to internal engine variables (these classes help in execution of tasks, analyzing the graph and performing other internal engine activities). Preparation ----------- This stage starts by setting up the storage needed for all tasks in the previously created graph, ensuring that corresponding :py:class:`~taskflow.persistence.logbook.AtomDetail` (or subclass of) objects are created for each node in the graph. Once this is done final validation occurs on the requirements that are needed to start execution and and what storage provides. If there is any task/flow requirements not satisfied then execution will not be allowed to continue. Execution --------- The graph (and helper objects) previously created are now activated. A :py:class:`~taskflow.engines.action_engine.graph_action.FutureGraphAction` object starts to take over and begins going through the stages listed below. Resumption ^^^^^^^^^^ One of the first stages is to analyze the state of the atoms in the graph, determining which ones have failed, which one were previously running and determining what the intention of that atom should now be (typically an intention can be that it should ``REVERT``, or that it should ``EXECUTE`` or that it should be ``IGNORED``). This intention is determined by analyzing the current state of the atom which is determined by looking at the state in the atom detail object for that atom and analyzing edges of the graph for things like retry nodes which can influence what an atoms intention should be. Once these intentions are determined and associated with each atom (the intention is also stored in the :py:class:`~taskflow.persistence.logbook.AtomDetail` object) the scheduling stage starts. Scheduling ^^^^^^^^^^ This stage selects which atoms are eligible to run (looking at there intention, checking if predecessor atoms have ran and so-on) and submits those atoms to a previously provided compatible `executor`_ for asynchronous execution. This executor will return a `future`_ object for each atom submitted; all of which are collected into a list of not done futures. This will end the initial round of scheduling and at this point the engine enters the waiting stage. Waiting ^^^^^^^ In this stage the engine waits for any of the future objects previously submitted to complete. Once one of the future objects completes (or fails) that atoms result will be examined and persisted to the persistence backend (saved into the corresponding :py:class:`~taskflow.persistence.logbook.AtomDetail` object) and the state of the atom is changed. At this point what happens falls into two categories, one for if that atom failed and one for if it did not. If the atom failed it may be set to a new intention such as ``RETRY`` or ``REVERT`` (other atoms that were predecessors of this failing atom may also have there intention altered). Once this intention adjustment has happened a new round of scheduling occurs and this process repeats until the engine succeeds or fails (if the process running the engine dies the above stages will be restarted and resuming will occur). .. note:: If suspension is triggered while the engine is going through the above stages this will stop any further scheduling stages from occurring and all currently executing atoms will be allowed to finish (and there results will be saved). .. _future: https://docs.python.org/dev/library/concurrent.futures.html#future-objects .. _executor: https://docs.python.org/dev/library/concurrent.futures.html#concurrent.futures.Executor .. _networkx: https://networkx.github.io/ .. automodule:: taskflow.engines.action_engine.engine .. automodule:: taskflow.engines.action_engine.graph_action

commit_message:
Correct metadata ordering issue in tests

Some test including test_volume_get_all_filters
fails randomly because metadata is in a dict and
the items order is undefined.
The test comparison was changed to avoid unexpected
test results.

Change-Id: Ibb24d21cd05aa1eefb45b61c63de067b34fb1013
Closes-Bug: #1293792
(cherry picked from commit 4cc2366623743393f89a198581fcb69dc04d31cd)

commit_message:
Specification for floatingip extension support for nuage plugin

Change-Id: I3c931c697dfb31320900ab07ff2f4a72b09fd1e2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/59/89459/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================================= FloatingIP Extension support for Nuage Plugin ============================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/floatingip-ext-for-nuage-plugin Adding floatingip extension support to existing nuage networks' Plugin Problem description =================== Current Nuage Plugin does not support Neutron's floatingip extension. Nuage's VSP supports this feature and the support for extension needs to be added in the plugin code. Proposed change =============== Adding extension support code in Nuage plugin. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- Existing floatingip tables in neutron will be added. On top of that, there will be 2 nuage specific tables which will be added: Schema could look like: ''' class FloatingIPPoolMapping(model_base.BASEV2): __tablename__ = "floatingip_pool_mapping" fip_pool_id = Column(String(36), primary_key=True) net_id = Column(String(36), ForeignKey('networks.id', ondelete="CASCADE")) router_id = Column(String(36), ForeignKey('routers.id', ondelete="CASCADE")) class FloatingIPMapping(model_base.BASEV2): __tablename__ = 'floatingip_mapping' fip_id = Column(String(36), ForeignKey('floatingips.id',ondelete="CASCADE"), primary_key=True) router_id = Column(String(36)) nuage_fip_id = Column(String(36)) ''' REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Its a straightforward floatingip extension support where resource from neutron will be mapped into VSP. When user creates external network and gives it a subnet, floatingip-pool will be created. When floatingip is created, its created in VSP as well. Associate, disassociate of floatingip with port should work in the same way as well. CRUD operation on floatinip will be supported in normal fashion. Assignee(s) ----------- Ronak Shah Primary assignee: ronak-malav-shah Other contributors: Work Items ---------- Extension code in Nuage plugin Nuage Unit tests addition Nuage CI coverage addition Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit Test coverage for floating-ip extension within Nuage unit test Nuage CI will be modified to start supporting this extension tests Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Disable oslo.messaging debug logs

oslo.messaging debug logs are too verbose, turn them off. A similar patch
dropped nova-conductor logs in the gate down from 7MB to under 300K.

Cherry-Pick from oslo-incubator since we are in feature freeze:
Ia12c003dae196e2220a5f6ea768758a75f2ede23 and
Icc61964c6a2b002ac1c8566f174e6a5230674c75

Closes-Bug: #1309626
(cherry picked from commit a24192d90938ea89b8f20132de60e6ad3a4ad447)
Change-Id: I9e6456f1c979d9a57fc7fa93fb290c6a26017373
